Award.AbstractNarration:
Research conducted under this grant will address two broad areas in the field of climate dynamics. The first consists of identification and interpretations of the atmospheric variability pattern associated with MJO in terms of variability in thin cirrus clouds, aerosols and geochemical tracers. The second consists of an analysis of time varying patterns of sea surface temperature (SST), sea level pressure (SLP) and surface air temperature over land (SAT) to explore (1) the interrelations between the fields and in particular, the processes that shape the dominant patterns in the SST field, (2) a prominent pattern of wintertime SLP variability, with maximum amplitude over Eurasia, and (3) patterns of SAT and SLP variability whose time-varying indices project upon hemispheric and regional-mean temperatures. The second research area is of interest for understanding recent climate change and determining the anthropogenic contribution to it.

The work will have broader impacts through the education of two graduate students. In addition, the work on climate change detection and attribution to anthropogenic or natural causes may benefit decision makers seeking to understand and respond to climate change and its impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant, entitled Projects in Climate Dynamics has funded a number of projects designed to illuminate the workings of the global atmospheric circulation. It has involved both research and education, conducted in collaboration with graduate research assistants, faculty colleagues, and researchers in the US, China, and  India. The work has advanced our understanding of a wide range of phenomena including El Niño, the primary source of year-to-year variability in the climate system, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), the primary source of interdecadal variability. and the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), which modulates the tropical circulation on a time scale of weeks. We have produced global climatologies of lightning and rain rate.  We have isolated the signature of the lunar gravitational tide in the Interim Reanalysis by the European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasting.  We have explored the teleconnections between climate anomalies over different parts of the globe. We have shown how year-to-year variations in surface winds over the Arctic have affected Arctic sea ice and, more generally, how natural variability has contributed to what is perceived as climate change. Much of the work is descriptive, based on statistical analysis of global observational datasets.

The grant has also supported the preparation of graphics for a textbook on the atmospheric general circulation designed for use in graduate curricula in weather and climate science.
